Award.AwardTitle: Homogenization of Elliptic and Parabolic Partial Differential Equations
Award.AbstractNarration:
The mathematical theory of homogenization identifies the average, macroscopic behavior of a phenomenon that is subject to microscopic effects. For example, one may be interested in determining the general properties of a porous material, or predicting the evolution of a substance traveling through a heterogeneous medium. Such phenomena are typically modeled by partial differential equations that depend on microscopic length-scales describing the heterogeneities. Homogenization is the process of approximating such detailed equations with smoother, macroscopic models. The principal investigator will focus on the subject of so-called stochastic homogenization, in which the microscopic effects are randomly distributed. Such models are significant for developing a robust framework to represent "typical" physical settings that are subject to uncertainty. Generally speaking, the study of homogenization combines tools from several different areas of mathematics, including analysis, partial differential equations, dynamical systems, and probability theory. The principal investigator is committed to using collaborative approaches to the project. This flexible perspective promotes a unified understanding of the physical phenomena, as well as enhancing the theory of the relevant equations.

The principal investigator will focus her efforts on two main classes of elliptic and parabolic partial differential equations: (a) non-divergence-form equations, which describe general diffusion processes and are frequently used in the study of stochastic control theory and geometry; and (b) reaction-diffusion equations, solutions of which represent front-like evolution and serve as the primary mathematical models in chemical kinetics, combustion, and biology. The research will encompass proposes a variety of sub-projects that are motivated by the following two objectives: (1) to show that homogenization is applicable to a broader class of partial differential equations than previously expected; and (2) to obtain more specific information about the process of homogenization than is currently known, such as error estimates or properties of the effective behavior. Questions posed initially in stochastic homogenization typically have equivalent formulations in probability theory. Consequently, the research may lead to progress in the study of random walks in random environments, first passage percolation, and large deviation principles.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project was driven by the subject of homogenization. The basic question in the field is to analyze how microscopic variations in the composition of a medium affect the macroscopic behavior of natural processes occurring in it. The goal is to show that on scales much larger than the scale of the variations in a heterogeneous medium, one effectively observes a homogeneous-medium behavior of the process in question (homogenization). The project had a particular emphasis on the study of stochastic homogenization, in which the microscopic variations in the heterogeneous medium are randomly distributed. The primary mathematical models to describe such problems are partial differerential equations with random variable coefficients. 

Mathematically speaking, stochastic homogenization is inherently interdisciplinary in nature; the subject requires a deep understanding of the partial differential equations in question and the relevant probabilistic tools necessary for analysis. In fact, many problems in stochastic homogenization can be formulated equivalently in purely probabilistic terms. Consequently, this work contributes towards clarifying the understanding and strengthening the connection between the fields of PDEs and probability. 

On a broader level, the subject of stochastic homogenization has numerous applications to mathematical modelling in other fields of science. The primary equations we studied (nondivergence form and reaction-diffusion) are frequently used in the modelling of diffusion processes, and population dynamics, combustion, and chemical kinetics respectively. Homogenization results have immediate physical interpretations in terms of identifying the "average behavior" of physical systems with uncertain environmental influences.

In the duration of this award, we made progress in several of the proposed projects. This included understanding the statistical properties of random solutions in the context of stochastic homogenization for nondivergence form elliptic equations, and furthering the general understanding of stochastic homogenization for reaction-diffusion equations.

During the 1-year of this award, I was invited to present my work related to this project at several meetings and research seminars nationally and internationally. In Summer 2017, I also organized an undergraduate summer school at the University of Wisconsin--Madison, as part of the National Science Foundation Research Training Grant: Analysis and Applications. I also gave a minicourse at this summer school titled "An Introduction to Weak Solutions for Nonlinear Partial Differential Equations," which introduced the foundational tools used to study the types of partial differential equations explored in this project.
